snippet: When Daniel St. Hubert was released from prison, there was little that correction officials could do to ensure that he received the therapy he needed. Nine days later, he was accused in a killing.
abstract: Case of Daniel St Hubert, who carried out bloody rampage in Brooklyn only days after being released from prison, illustrates how difficult it is to determine if mentally ill prisoners are fit to return to their communities; correction officials and mental health providers face difficult choices between civil liberty protections and concerns for public safety; number of treatment tools and regulations exist, but there are still many ways for dangerous, mentally unstable people to slip through cracks.

byline.original: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ, MARC SANTORA and PAM BELLUCK
byline.contributor: Stephanie Clifford and Joseph Goldstein contributed reporting. Jack Begg contributed research.

headline.main: Stabbing Case Shows Lapses in Treatment for the Mentally Ill
headline.print_headline: Found Fit for Release, Then Charged in Killing
